segments.text: This is going to be your personal opinion, but I'm trying to build up a consensus, if there is one, by adding up personal opinion.
What do you think the taxpayers and the general public in this country think of planetary astronomy in particular and just astronomy in general?
I think the public's very interested in astronomy.
And to the average person on the street, planetary astronomy is probably most of astronomy.
I mean, they've heard a lot from Sagan, which emphasizes, although not exclusively, planetary astronomy.
And they see stuff in the media frequently on sexy things like black holes, but they don't understand them.

On the other hand, if you show them a picture of Jupiter or a satellite of the outer solar system or a volcano on Mars, they'll figure out quite quickly where it was, how that image was obtained, and maybe in some cases be able to tell you why they'd like to see more.
So I think, in fact, it's extremely important for science in this country to continue the planetary program with vigor.
Do you think the public ought to have that view?
Sure.
Why not?
It doesn't matter.
It's close.
It's easier to touch.
You can see Jupiter at night and recognize it.
To point out to your kids that it's not just a star, but it's a big, giant, gaseous world with little planets around it.
Why not?
Here's another two-part question.
And your viewpoint is probably fairly important here.
Do you think planetary astronomers have done a good job of selling themselves to the public and Congress?
And do you think that astronomers as a whole have done a good job doing that?
It's hard to answer.
The second one I can answer, recently I think there's been some counter examples or examples of negative salesmanship, bickering,
to Congress trying to go pork and anti-pork for things like the Gemini project, probably quite counterproductive.
So politicizing future projects with NSF and NASA as the funding agency is probably a bad idea.
As far as planetary astronomy being successful, well, you'd like to think so.
On the other hand, look at the number of missions planned and canceled of late.
So in fact, from that aspect,
despite the fact that these things are moderately inexpensive compared to manned exploration of near Earth environment or anything else.
They aren't getting full funding.
It's just a tough time for space science, I suppose.
We've both done some optical and some radio astronomy.
First of all, radio astronomy never had a sneering attitude towards planetary work.
Now, is this just because the planets were bright sources that could be identified?
Or was it because both of them in the 50s had this pariah status?
Well, I'm not sure the radio astronomers had pariah status.
They were just regarded as different, because their backgrounds weren't as enough.
They were engineers, and they certainly knew how to use slide rule.
some electronic test equipment.
Soldering iron.
It's definitely a soldering iron and plenty of solder.
I wasn't completely scorned.
I don't know.
No, I think they were treated differently.
They may have been not mainstream, but I don't think they were particularly pariahs.
And as far as planetary astronomy making an impact, as soon as Jupiter was just slightly beyond discovered at low frequency from the first radiation by
Franklin and Burke, right?
Then Venus got detected, I think, in 56 or 57 first.
No one believed it quite that fast.
With a high brightness temperature.
And after a little while, we realized that that wouldn't go away.
And you had to figure out what the reason was.
So that played a big role around 1960, plus or minus three on each side of 1960, in the development of planetary physics.

How come with this future planning and tenure plans and all this sort of stuff, the radio astronomers always seem to have their fights and their bloodlettings behind locked doors and come out with a unified thing, whereas the optical people stage public spectacles?
Why does this always continue?
I mean, I've heard this repeated many times.
I don't know the answer.
I mean, it's a sensible part of science to disagree on technical details.
That's normal.
but you're not supposed to involve Congress in it.
Which doesn't understand the technical details in general.
Definitely not, and probably doesn't care.
And once they hear some argument, they figure, oh, both of these sides are quite silly, and let's listen to them for a few minutes and go on to something more serious.
Yeah, I don't know the answer to that, but it does seem to always be the case.
I would have thought we'd got over that 10 years ago.
I mean, even the high-energy physicists have gotten their act together, which with that bunch of,
Queen Bee seems incredible.
Yeah, I don't know how black and white the situation is.
I'm pretty unplugged to that.

But certainly, ever since I got to think about astropolitics, it's always been the case that the radio astronomers have been well enough prepared in advance that they had a chance to get something while the optical folks bit and scratched, mostly scratched each other pretty badly.
Now with some exceptions, I mean the National Observatory in the early days at least went quickly from an 0.9 to a 2.1 to 2.4 meter telescopes, but after that it's pretty much turned off.
Planetary Astronomies found out a lot of things about the solar system in the last 30 years.
All you have to do is compare Baker's 7th edition or something like that and it's just a whole different solar system.
Do you think that's really changed the way the general public thinks about anything?
I've got a whole list here, the way they've thought about Earth, solar system, the universe, planetary astronomy, astronomy.
Can you be more explicit?
I mean, give me an example.
Has it really changed the way people think about, well, for example, science?
Do you think that all these discoveries have made people say, hey, these scientists can really do something.
They can really find out stuff.
I think they've thought that that's the case.
since World War II.
I think the application of science to the conflict, World War II and the Cold War, told people that science was important, if not necessarily completely without disqualification or sin.

There's been a lot of, I don't know if you want to call it pseudo-philosophical comments to the effect that now that we can get out and see that Earth is just one little planet among others and all this sort of stuff.
Do you think that's really affected the general public?
Slightly from the ecological point of view, but not enormously.
I think the lumber companies are still quite happy to cut all the old growth and the owls be damned.
OK. 30 years ago, there was still a chance that there was life on Mars.
And now we've been to all the major planets except Pluto, and no evidence so far of any life on any planet, particularly no little green men on Mars, not even a bug.
Do you think that's had any effect on funding and public interest for planetary astronomy, astronomy, and science in general?
I don't think so.
I don't think so.
Anyway, we haven't explored Jupiter thoroughly, right?
I mean, there's still possibilities for floaters.
The alternative is if they would have found one microbe on Mars.
We'd be standing there now probably.
That's true.

I mean, certainly if the results had been very, very different from Viking's more or less negative results, that we'd want to track it down or certainly make sure it wasn't something we carried along.
Yep, hitchhikers are welcome.
Yes, I agree with what you're saying.
But I don't think it's had an enormously negative effect, because I think most people are slightly cynical and didn't really expect to see much.
It would have been interesting if they had found fossils.
Hard to do experiments on.
We don't know that.
We still may.
Of course, the only two lander probes were landed for engineering reasons.
Absolutely.
They're lousy places to look for anything interesting because they don't have previous water flow history.
Now, unfortunately, this question that I
that I wrote down here.
It says your institution, but Lick is now separate from Berkeley, but isn't in all the states.
Lick is a statewide institution, per se.
It's called Organized Research Unit, and it serves all campuses.
Well, then let's just take Berkeley here.
You mentioned how Carl came here for a while and got interest started.
And you still have some interest in planetary astronomy.
Do you have any planetary astronomy group here or anything like that?
Not really a group, but Imke de Potter is very interested and works
almost full-time on planetary problems, radio mostly, radio magnetospheres, radio thermal radiation from all the planets.
She's had a student who just finished a thesis on the thermal radiation from Mercury as measured radio interferometry.
So there's a bit going on.
Also, the geology department would like to be in it.
They're not quite sure how to do that.
So there's interest in geology, but nothing much yet to show for it.
How come this place never developed a strong
planetary things.
Other things?
Just breaks of the game.
A lot of strong people in other fields.
It's hard to cover every base.
We don't have much in solar.
But never any implied attitude that you shouldn't do that?
No.
What do you think the taxpayers got out of the money they funneled into the space program over there?
the past 30 years of planetary astronomy?
Oh, a lot.
A lot, because it's a wonderful frontier.
More in planetary, more tangible stuff in planetary than anything else.
And we can point to moon rocks and say, hey, if you're interested, we'll tell you how old that rock is.
That rock is older than anything you walked on.
Probably.
Probably.
So, yeah, I think they've done reasonably well.
I mean, you know, it's hard to justify the bucks for a launch, but what can you do?
I think they've gotten a lot of thrills, too.
You think planetary astronomy is a real...
accepted now by most other astronomers?
Most.
Most.
Still a few hold out.
Maybe.
Not that many.
But, you know, I don't like all kinds of astronomy.
Some of mine knows that, but there's some things I wouldn't bother to do.
A lot of people have been getting a lot of mileage lately in the, quote, planetary, unquote, field.
I just wrote down four things here.
There might be more.
One is the search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
One is search for other solar systems.
Another one is the
hole in Earth's ozone layer, and one finding and deflecting killer asteroids and comets.
So you think they've overdone that?
Well, not that much.
I mean, the ozone hole is real, right?
So you hardly want to see your grandchildren have to wear a Dodger hat every time they go out in the sun in 20 years.
So that's something that clearly is a man-made
situation, which can be probably improved by ecological care in the future.
So that's probably, obviously, the most important thing.
SETI is the most whimsical, but still has a small outside chance of success.
And there, of course, the stakes are very large.
So it's like a lottery.
And that would be exciting.
And I'd be somewhat cynical about the chances for instant success.
But who knows?
Killer asteroids?
The statistics are fairly straightforward that there are asteroid impacts that are going to release a lot of kinetic energy.
Certainly going to ruin the Tuesday tea party.
Yeah.
Right.
So that's fine whether you can deflect them or want to deflect them if you knew enough how to do that.
This is a different constituency, which might not be my favorite fans.
Other solar systems are...
likely events, and we don't quite know how to find them.
When you find a dust cloud around Beta Pictoris, that's fine.
Whether that really has anything to do with another solar system is unknown, but it's a kind of lead we would like to follow up in a variety of ways.
So looking, for example, for objects of few Jovian masses by regular velocities of the apparent star are projects going on now which are quite worthwhile and don't tap the resources very deeply.
should continue, and the chances of success are hard to measure, but probably pretty good.
Here's a question, and I think you can put them together, because both planetary astronomers and regular astronomers are complaining about the budget crunch.
But of course, there's even now vastly more money per astronomer available than there was in the late 1950s, right?
Yeah, because then there wasn't any.
We learned to do without.
But that wasn't so good.
I mean, use it up, wear it out, make it do.
We learned that.
And that's not necessarily the most efficient way to proceed.
It does make you self-reliant.
But what do you think about, and I'll lump together planetary astronomy with astronomy, because if somebody pulls the plug in the bathtub, all the little rubber duckies are going to ground.
What's the state of it today?
Plateau?
Seems like a plateau, but the problem is
The number of people who want money are increasing, and expectations are increasing sort of proportional to the prospects in the field, which are good.
So it's a disappointment in the sense that our expectations get higher all the time.
So the exponent is greater than one.
Yeah, I think so.
And, well, would you agree that it just can't keep increasing at the rate it's been doing, say, during the 70s or during the 60s?
Yeah, there it was very high.
But it could increase a little bit, keep us from fighting among ourselves all the time for the remaining scraps.
There are more degree-granting institutions than ever, and more new PhDs than ever.
How long can that go on?
Not forever.
We've got more than we need.
Right.
I mean, you just can't employ them all game through.
Also, there's a rather substantial influx of astronomers from other fields.
So it isn't just that we're training too many PhDs, but the field is successful.
The numbers I've heard quoted around recently is something like 135, roughly, PhDs per year in astronomy.
And there aren't nearly that many positions.
So they often go into postdocs as a holding position for some years.
On the other hand, the number of people calling themselves astronomers or becoming members of AAS increases at about twice that rate.
So it must mean an influx from physics and other associated fields.
So even if we were to cut back enormously in productivity
new PhDs, it wouldn't completely solve the problem.
We forgot to go into some detail about Gerard de Bacallure, who was unusual in that he did planetary and galaxy research.
Right.
He walked both sides of the street in a very unusual way in the 1950s, 60s, and even later.
He was a good advocate of planetary astronomy.
Wrote a good book on Mars, which was
distillation of many observations.
Not all of them survived, but it was influential.
And he did very good stuff on galaxies, probably was one of the leader in statistical work on galaxy properties from Hubble's death to maybe 1970.
Quite an impressive guy to be able to do that that well.
So I shouldn't have omitted him earlier, but certainly he was a well-respected person that could do either.

Well, we just noticed that when you applied for telescope time at McDonald in early 1963, de Bacalhau wrote you a letter dated February 4, 1963, in which he said there's a good possibility of JPL buying time at McDonald Observatory.
And he sounded quite favorable on that.
Right.
So I'm not sure what happened next.
Obviously, it never panned out.
It was never a penny spent.
He recommends that you send a formal application to Dr. W.W. Morgan at Yerkes Observatory.
And then here's the next letter saying, in a famous phrase we both remember, a famous sentence, I regret to have to inform you that the observing program for the McDonnell 82-inch is saturated.
And I would have supposed that you would have made arrangements through Caltech to obtain observing time locally.
These were very frustrating times.
It's interesting that Morgan actually was a nicer guy than I thought at the time.
So I don't think he was particularly mad at me.
It's interesting that just a year and a half later, McDonald completely opened up to planetary work.
Yes, right, but it wasn't because of either of those people, although DeVocalor certainly wouldn't have minded.
No, that was Smitty's influence, which had an enormous positive change there.
